claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since the 1980s.

attacks.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since the 1980s.
The increase in working hours may be skewed by part-time workers shifting to full-time employment, not necessarily longer hours for the same individuals.
Even if part-time shifts contribute, official data still reflects a net increase in total working hours per capita across the population.
Modern remote work and flexible schedules mean reported 'working hours' may include unproductive time, unlike stricter historical workplace monitoring.
Productivity metrics confirm output-per-hour has risen consistently, suggesting reported working hours remain a meaningful comparison.

supporting.text: The rise of gig economy jobs has led to more people working longer or irregular hours compared to traditional employment patterns.

attacks.text: The rise of gig economy jobs has led to more people working longer or irregular hours compared to traditional employment patterns.
Gig economy workers represent a small fraction of the total workforce, so their impact on overall working hours is limited.
Even if gig workers are a minority, their increasing numbers and influence can shift norms and expectations for other workers.
Many gig economy jobs offer flexibility, allowing workers to choose shorter hours if desired, which may not increase total working time.
Flexibility often leads to overwork due to lack of fixed schedules and pressure to maximize earnings in precarious jobs.

supporting.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to increased perceived working hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to increased perceived working hours.
Studies show that actual working hours in England have decreased over the past decades due to labor laws and improved work-life balance policies.
Perceived working hours may not reflect actual productivity, as technology also enables more efficient task completion.
The blurring of boundaries primarily affects knowledge workers, while many sectors (e.g., manufacturing) maintain strict separation of work and personal time.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages relative to living costs, have forced many workers to take on additional jobs or overtime.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages relative to living costs, have forced many workers to take on additional jobs or overtime.
Productivity gains and automation have reduced the need for longer working hours in many sectors.
Despite productivity gains, wage stagnation means workers still need to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Government policies and labor laws have increasingly promoted work-life balance, reducing average working hours.
Many workers are in precarious employment where labor laws are not effectively enforced, leading to longer hours despite policies.

supporting.text: Historical data indicates that standard working hours were reduced during the mid-20th century due to labor movements, but recent trends show a reversal in this pattern.

attacks.text: Historical data indicates that standard working hours were reduced during the mid-20th century due to labor movements, but recent trends show a reversal in this pattern.
The claim overlooks the rise of part-time and flexible work arrangements, which may offset the increase in standard working hours for some demographics.
Part-time work does not necessarily reduce total working hours if individuals hold multiple jobs or engage in gig economy work.
Technological advancements have increased productivity, potentially reducing the need for longer working hours despite trends suggesting otherwise.
Higher productivity often leads to increased workloads rather than reduced hours, as employers capitalize on efficiency gains.
